subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 9th: Fed bazooka sees stocks rally; OPEC+ reach agreement
content:

April 9th: Fed bazooka sees stocks rally; OPEC+ reach agreement

 

·        SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.

·        REARVIEW: USD 2.3trln loan provision announced by the Fed, supports junk credit; OPEC+ to cut 10-12mln BPD; Congress blocks additional small business lending programme funding.

·        WEEK IN FOCUS: MON: Easter Monday - UK & EU Markets closed, US Markets open; IMF/World Bank Spring Meeting, Bank of Indonesia Monetary Policy Decision. TUE: Chinese Trade Balance (Mar), Australia NAB Survey (Mar). WED: BoC Monetary Policy Decision, French and Italian CPI (Mar), Swedish CPIF (Mar), US Retail Sales and Industrial Production (Mar), NY Fed Manufacturing (Apr), South Korean National Assembly Election, IEA Oil Market Report. THU: Australian Labour Market Report (Mar), German CPI (Mar/F), EZ Industrial Production (Feb), US Initial Jobless Claims (w/e Apr 11), US Philly Fed (Apr), OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report. FRI: Chinese GDP (Q1), Retail Sales (Mar) and Industrial Production (Mar); EZ CPI (Mar/F). To download the report, please click here.

·        CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: Reviewing Fed minutes, Powell, ECB minutes; Previewing BOC. To download the report, please click here.

MARKET WRAP

Markets were firmer on Thursday after the Fed’s latest announcement of a USD 2.3trln loan provision bazooka, which includes a Main Street lending programme. The new adjustments in the Fed’s liquidity facilities give support to fallen angel companies, those recently downgraded to junk status, as well as supporting high yield ETFs. The latest provisions saw the financials (XLF) sector lead major bourses higher; the DX was sold heavily and XAU made solid gains. Meanwhile, energy (XLE) traded in the red as oil prices settled lower in anticipation of the G20 oil meeting on Friday; note, Thursday’s OPEC plus meeting resulted in Saudi and Russia agreeing to both cut to 8.5mln BPD output as part of a group total 10mln BPD cut for two months. Another blockbuster jobless claims report (6.6mln vs exp. 4.6mln) and the University of Michigan (preliminary for April) survey printing its steepest ever decline failed to stop the rally, as participants continue to look past near-term data.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

·        US cases rise 8.7% to 427,460 (prev. +5.5% at 395,011), death toll rises 15.2% to 14,696 (prev. +6% at 12,754).

·        NEW YORK cases rise 7.1% to 159,937 (prev. +7.5% at 149,316), death toll rises by 12.7% to 7,067 (prev. +14.2% at 6,268)

·        ITALY cases rise 2.9% to 143,625 (Prev. 139,442, +2.8%); death toll +16% 8,729 (Prev. 17,669, +3.2%).

·        UK death toll rises 12.4% to 7,978 (prev. +15.2% at 7,097)

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: President Trump called on Congress to the pass loan programme funding this week and stated that a phase 4 stimulus bill could be done later. However, the additional loan programme was voted against by Congress on Thursday, as lawmakers had indicated. Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said on CNBC that airlines (UAL, DAL, AAL, LUV, JBLU…) would be the next part of the stimulus bill to be rolled out; added that discussions would be held with the Fed for companies which don’t fit into the new facilities. Mnuchin also said that there are currently no discussions at the moment for the Fed to purchase stocks.

LOCKDOWN: President Trump said we are much closer to getting the country back to where it was before the coronavirus and he sees signs that efforts to slow the spread of the virus are working. Furthermore, Trump suggested the government could re-open the country in phases and possibly ahead of schedule. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said in the CNBC interview that is is possible that businesses could open in May. NEC Director Kudlow said on Fox Business News that the economy should be able to re-open on a “rolling basis” in the next month or two.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED MSLP: The Fed on Thursday announced further details with regards to its Main Street Lending Programme, what involves USD 2.3trln of loans to support the economy; this gains its authority from the USD 450bln allocation the Treasury received in the Cares Act that will act to indemnify the Fed against losses. Capital Economics explains that, in most of the specific facilities, the Fed will be leveraging the Treasury’s capital at a ratio of 10:1; the loan programmes will bolster the Small Business Administration’s paycheck protection programme, it will also lend to SMEs. The Fed is also setting up a USD 500bln facility to help state and Local Governments. “The upshot is that, assuming the Fed continues to buy Treasury securities, albeit at a gradually reduced pace, the Fed’s balance sheet, which has ballooned from USD 4trln to USD 6trln, will hit USD 10trln within another couple of months,” CapEco wrote.

FED CHAIR POWELL: Fed Chair Powell gave remarks at the end of the week that revealed little by way of new information, although he reiterated some recent themes. He said the US was moving with alarming speed towards very high unemployment, although it would be temporary. The Fed can provide some relief and stability now, and it can use tools to ensure eventual recovery is vigorous as possible, Powell said, adding that the central bank was deploying emergency lending powers to an unprecedented extent, with backing from Congress and the Treasury, and would use lending powers “forcefully, aggressively, and proactively” until recovery is on a solid footing.

BOE: The BoE and the Treasury have announced a temporary extension of the Ways & Means facility. As a temporary measure, this will provide a short-term source of additional liquidity to the government if needed to smooth its cash flows and support the orderly functioning of markets, through the period of disruption from COVID-19.

ECB PRESIDENT LAGARDE said there should not be a fixation on Coronabonds (joint issuance), as things take time in Europe; said there could be other forms of European mutualised spending via a shared budget or a reconstruction fund. Furthermore, in Il Sole 24, Lagarde said budgetary and monetary policies need to be aligned, and equal conditions for all are needed, if not all countries are taken care of, then others will suffer as a result. The ECB President also noted that she believes the Euro’s value is stable and the level is “fine”, adding that she would like more inflation.

ECB MINUTES: The minutes from the ECB’s 12th and 18th March meetings revealed that the central bank viewed the economic situation to be deteriorating rapidly, leading them to take unprecedented action. Financial conditions were judged to be worsening, running the risk that financial conditions would tighten in a procyclical manner. All members agreed that a further forceful monetary policy response was warranted, and there was broad support expressed for the package of measures proposed by chief economist Lane, with some nuances of views regarding specific elements of the proposal. However, there were some reservations expressed with regards to the proposed communication on the issue share and issuer limits, and these limits were one of the safeguards to ensure that the governing council acted within its mandate. There was unanimous agreement that bold and decisive action was needed to counter the serious risks posed by the rapidly spreading coronavirus, with the central bank noting that there appeared to be sufficient scope in the evolution of the purchasable universe to avoid a premature discussion on a possible lifting of these limits. A strong response was also seen to underline the credibility of the ECB’s commitment to using all of its monetary policy instruments. Analysts at ING said the minutes illustrate the ECB’s road to another ‘whatever it takes’ moment and suggest that both a rate cut and more quantitative easing should not be ruled out. “If anything, additional rate cuts should not be ruled outentirely, as some ECB members still seem to supportthem. More generally, the U-turn by Christine Lagarde to do whatever it takes clearly suggests that the ECB stands ready to do more, if need be.”

BOJ: BoJ Governor Kuroda said the spread of the coronavirus is having a severe impact on Japan’s economy through exports, output, inbound tourists and a slump in consumption. Noting uncertainty on Japan’s outlook is extremely high and investor risk sentiment has soured, while markets destabilised rapidly. Kuroda added the financial system maintains soundness as a whole, but corporate funding strains are worsening. Kuroda said the BoJ would conduct commercial paper and corporate bond-buying operations to ensure corporate funding is smooth, adding the BoJ will not hesitate to take additional easing steps as required while keeping a close eye on the impact to the economy from COVID-19.

RBA: The RBA financial stability review noted financial market uncertainty is elevated and that many households will find finances under strain due to efforts to contain the virus. The review highlighted the volatility caused by the pandemic but added capital levels are high and banks’ liquidity position improved over recent times, adding banks entered the downturn with high profitability and very good asset performance.

BOK kept the 7-day Repo Rate unchanged at 0.75% (as expected) through a split decision as board members Cho Dong-Chul and Shin In-Seok dissented, in which they advocated a 25bps cut. BoK stated it has policy room to respond to slowing growth and will increase outright purchases of government bonds if required. At the same time, Governor Lee commented they are seeing an impact of the previous rate cut and will announce plans to buy government bonds.

EUROPE

EUROGROUP: A deal was reached for an economic support package in the Eurogroup meeting, announced late on Thursday. Tony Connelly at RTE said, citing a source, “The ESM element has been agreed, the European Commission’s SURE package, mobilising up to 100bn has been agreed, + the EIB pan European guarantee scheme has been agreed. Netherlands on board.”

UK LOCKDOWN / JOHNSON: PM Johnson is out of intensive care and is in “extremely good” spirits, will receive close monitoring during the early phase of his recovery, according to an official statement. Senior Ministers are reviewing the UK’s lockdown in Thursday’s COBRA meeting, some ministers reportedly believe a decision to ease restrictions will not be taken until PM Johnson returns. Additionally, expectations are for an extension into May. Note, the current Parliamentary legislation mandates a review of the lockdown before next Thursday.

EU LOCKDOWN: German Health Minister said infection numbers indicate a positive trend, and if it continues, the gov’t can talk about a gradual easing of lockdown measures; there were separate reports in Handelsblatt that Germany is mulling a loosening of restrictions after Easter. In Italy, the country could see an extension to its lockdown of another 15-days, where Italian PM Conte is reportedly to announce a new decree Friday confirming such, according to La Stampa.

DATA

INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS: Jobless claims dipped slightly in the week, to 6.61mln from a revised up 6.87mln, topping the consensus 5mln. Analysts note that over the last four readings, jobless claims have totalled 17.1mln - that compares to the 220k trend rate ahead of the COVID fallout, suggesting that the number of excess claims has risen to 16.2mln. Pantheon Macroeconomics says next week's number will also be huge, but likely lower than this week: "Google searches for 'file for unemployment' are now falling consistently on a W/W basis, by about one third," and "if that trend continues, we’d expect headline claims next week to drop to about 4.5M." The consultancy explains that this implies excess claims between the March and April payroll survey weeks will total some 20.1mln. "The hit to payrolls should be a bit less than that, because the gap between the surveys this time is five weeks rather than four, but even after allowing for this, we reckon May payrolls will be reported falling by about 19mln, driving the unemployment rate to 16% if none of the newly-unemployed leave the labor force." Pantheon says that seems unlikely, given that the labor force reportedly dropped by 1.6mln in March, when household employment fell by 3.0mln. "If that proportion repeats in April, headline unemployment will be about 10%, matching the peak after the Great Recession, but the true rate will be much higher, and it will rise further, along with the published rate, over the next few months."

CANADA EMPLOYMENT: Canada jobs data was grim, with headline employment -1mln jobs M/M deeper than the expected decline of 350k in March, the first employment report to show the impacts the coronavirus is taking on the Canadian labour market. Employment rose to 7.8% from 5.6%, above expectations of 7.2%. Both full time and part-time jobs were down heavily, full time -474k, part-time -537k. The participation rate saw its largest fall to 63.5% from 65.1%. RBC notes the layoffs are heavily surrounding lower-wage service sector industries adding the worst is yet to come in April. The desk highlights the decline next month could be “multiples of this March drop” as almost 3mln people have applied for employment loss benefits since the middle of March labour force survey.

CRUDE

WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 2.33 LOWER AT USD 22.76/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 1.36 LOWER AT USD 31.48/BBL

The crude complex danced to the rhythm of the evolving OPEC+ meeting, ahead of the G20 oil meeting Friday, although ultimately moved lower into settlement as participants likely closed out positions heading into the long weekend. Headlines note that the May/June contango rose to over USD 6/bbl, the widest front-month spread since 2009. At time of writing, sources have reported that Saudi and Russia have agreed to both cut oil output to 8.5mln BPD in the OPEC+ deal from May to June, which would mark a 2.79mln BPD cut from Russia and 3.8mln BPD from Saudi compared to April levels. More broadly, several sources said, including the Iranian Oil Minister, that OPEC+ is set to discuss a 10-12mln BPD cut from May to June, and then an 8mln BPD cut from July to December 2020, then a 6mln BPD cut from Jan 2021 to April 2022. The Iranian Oil Minister gave some more colour, saying Iran, Venezuela, and Libya are exempt from the cuts, with the touted cuts separate from the cuts expected of countries such as Brazil, Norway, and the US. Ahead of the Friday’s G20 meeting, which will see the likes of the US, Canada, and Norway come to the negotiating table, Canada’s Alberta Premier said the province has not been asked to cut output further and has made it clear to the US and OPEC that it has already curtailed output. Analysts have noted previously that it is most likely that the US and Canada will draw attention to the production cuts already taking place across their respective industries rather than agree to a government-enforced quota of such. The Alberta Premier went on to say that the municipal was getting very receptive responses from both Washington and Ottawa to placing tariffs on foreign oil if OPEC does not “stop the madness”. Click here for a complete collection of OPEC meeting related headlines.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 13 TICKS HIGHER AT 138-08.

The TPLEX traded choppy again as participants digested the latest Fed bazooka, gyrating OPEC+ sentiment, and minimal supply ahead of the long, Easter weekend. By settlement, yields were lower across the curve, lead by the belly, 2s -3bps at 0.23%, 5s -6bps at 0.41%, 10s -4bps at 0.72%, and 30s -1bps at 1.35%. Risk appetite had gotten off on the backfoot in European trade, as equity futures trundled lower alongside yields before the Fed announced its USD 2.3trln loan provision facilities which reversed the moves and nudged equities into a rally. The strength in Spooz going into the US session saw rates back up. However, the rally plateaued shortly after the cash equity open and saw support return for USTs - likely a function of jitters around the OPEC+ meeting and investors cutting risk exposure ahead of the long weekend. Meanwhile, corporate supply was sparse on Thursday, with no IG issuers in the dollar market, and with the Treasury’s auction reopenings out the way, there has been less selling pressure in Treasuries. Elsewhere, in credit, high-yield spreads narrowed on Thursday after the Fed’s latest announcement to support COVID-19 fallen angels (corporates that have seen their credit ratings downgraded to junk due to virus fallout), as well as high yield ETFs, with the day seeing a slew of headlines noting the spike higher in bonds of names such as Occidental (OXY) and Ford (F), amongst others. In the rates complex, three-month USD LIBOR posted a chunky 9bps decline for Thursday’s fixing, seeing the Eurodollar white pack stage a strong rally after Wednesday’s selling.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +1.45% at 2790, NDX +0.11% at 8239, DJIA +1.22% at 23,719.

SECTORS: Financials +5.19%, Real Estate +5.15%, Utilities +4.75%, Materials +4.27%, Industrials +1.43%, Cons Disc +1.43%, Cons Stpl +0.79%, Communication Svs +0.69%, Health +0.56%, Technology +0.02%, Energy -1.08%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Energy names remain in focus amid the ongoing OPEC+ deal. Note, Saudi and Russia reportedly agreed to both cut oil output to 8.5mln BPD in the OPEC+ deal. Saudi Arabia’s Sovereign wealth fund took stakes worth approximately USD 1bln in four major European oil companies, Equinor (EQNR NO), Shell (RDS.A LN), Total (FP FP) and Eni (ENI IM), according to sources, a Saudi official added they would not be surprised if we see similar deals again. Airlines (LUV, DAL, AAL, UAL) aid worth USD 29bln for the sector is reportedly being delayed as companies have been required to provide more detailed financial data to regulators in an already lengthy process. Meanwhile, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin states airline aid is the next to be rolled out. Goldminers (NEM, GOLD) firmer amid higher gold prices following the Fed’s latest additional USD 2.3trln loan facility to support the economy. Pfizer Inc. (PFE) has reportedly found a promising but early treatment for the coronavirus, which it aims to begin testing in patients this summer, it found the experimental drug could slow or stop the spread of the virus in patients with mild to moderate symptoms. Microchip Technology (MCHP) announced it is cutting costs while expecting quarterly revenue to increase by 3% (exp. -3.3%, prev. forecast 0%). MCHP noted the strength in bookings could be due to worries about supply chain disruptions, but it expects product demand is likely to weaken significantly. Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) net sales in March at USD 15.49bln, +11.7% Y/Y. Total comparable sales +9.6%, ex-fuel +12.3%. Starbucks (SBUX) expects a Q2 20 EPS at USD 0.32/shr, - USD 0.15-0.18 from prior guidance and expects Q3 impact to be significantly greater and to extend into Q4. General Electric (GE) withdrew its financial guidance due to the coronavirus, noting its preliminary view expects an impact on Adj. EPS to be USD 0.10 beneath prior guidance. Also expects Q1 industrial free cash flow to be near prior guidance of USD -2bln. Align Technology (ALGN) named a new short at Spruce Point Capital.

FOREX

FED BANGS THE BUCK, BUT BOOSTS BROAD RISK SENTIMENT

DXY: It’s debatable whether or not the Dollar was heading for a fall anyway given another record rise in the number of US initial claims, but the Fed removed doubt by unveiling its latest in an increasingly long line of credit easing packages at precisely the same time. In short, no less than Usd2.3 tn will be made available via an array of funding facilities including a Usd600 bn Main Street Lending Program targeting SMEs. The index tried to retain sight of the 100.000 mark, but could not withstand the weight of all round Greenback selling against major rivals and EM currencies as the aggressive stimulus gave flagging risk appetite a fillip. Indeed, the DXY declined to fresh wtd lows just a fraction above 99.400 compared to almost 101.000 at best and remained under pressure through downbeat/dovish commentary from Fed chair Powell pledging even more support for the economy without limit in terms of size, time or scope. From a chart perspective, April 2’s 99.335 now looms large.

AUD/NZD/CAD: The Aussie and Kiwi have gleaned more than fellow G10s from their US peer’s demise, as Aud/Usd probes above 0.6300 and Nzd/Usd tags along to top 0.6060, but the Loonie is also benefiting from a more pronounced rebound in crude prices amidst reports that OPEC+ and other global oil producers are planning to discuss an output cut of 20 mn bpd, even more than the 10-15 mn initially alluded to by US President Trump. In fact, Usd/Cad has posted a new weekly base at 1.3930 vs 1.4260 or so at the apex even though Canadian employment slumped by more than 1 mn in March ahead of next week’s BoC policy meeting.

GBP/EUR/CHF/JPYP: Sterling has spent the bulk of the week monitoring the health of UK PM Johnson, but did stumble after a raft of data and especially yawning trade deficits against consensus and previous balances. However, the Pound eventually mustered enough momentum to breach several technical hurdles that had been hampering upside progress alongside updates from the hospital indicating that he is responding well to medication and in a more stable condition. Cable eclipsed 1.2475 and Eur/Gbp crossed through 200 DMA and Fib levels on the way to circa 0.8727 before the single currency reclaimed 1.0900+ status vs the Buck with some independent impetus via remarks from Germany’s Finance Minister Scholz suggesting that the Eurogroup is likely to find a resolution on a fiscal package to counter the COVID-19 economic fallout. Elsewhere, the renowned safe havens have not been sticking strictly to their roles, as overall swings in sentiment have intermingled with daily updates and vigils on nCoV cases and fatality rates. Meanwhile, the Franc and Yen have also been conscious of Swiss and Japanese efforts to cushion the blow from the global pandemic and both relatively contained within 0.9797-0.9651 and 109.37-108.36 parameters respectively, though ending the EU week close to peaks given the aforementioned Dollar weakness.

SCANDI/EM: Notwithstanding several hiccups and negative factors like disappointing data and general bouts of risk aversion, the Norwegian and Swedish Crowns remain on course to net hefty gains against the Euro (and Greenback), with the Nok bolstered by a full week of bigger Norges Bank purchases and Sek drawing encouragement from evidence that containment is having a positive effect on flattening the coronavirus curve elsewhere. Meanwhile, the Rouble and Mexican Peso have been supported by more stable Brent and WTI pending the outcome of OPEC+ and others, while the Real has clawed back from all time lows on BCB vibes after the Governor pledged to embark on more aggressive intervention. Similarly, the Rand and Lira have both pared heavy losses on better fundamental news in the form of Eskom contending that it has sufficient funds for the rest of the year and will not need to ask the SA Government to provide more financial assistance, while Turkey is said to have held constructive talks with the IMF.

subject: IMPORTANT: Newsquawk Easter Schedule
content:
• The desk will operate its usual schedule until Thursday April 9th 2130BST upon which the desk will close and remain closed for the entirety of Friday 10th April in observance of Good Friday with UK, EU and US markets all closed.    
  • The Service will resume on Sunday April 12th at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 13th April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

subject: A draft EU coronavirus agreement says the national leaders are to decide on whether innovative financial instruments should be used to finance the recovery, according to a document
content: • Access to ESM credit lines will be available until the coronavirus crisis is over, but afterwards Euro area should remain committed to strengthening economic and financial fundamentals

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
Full newsquawk preview available here (8 Apr)

DEAL HOW IT STANDS CURRENTLY

  • After a disagreement with Mexico, the nation later agreed to the deal and everyone came to an agreement. Overall, OPEC+agree to cut overall output by 10mln BPD from May 1st 2020 for 2 months, then 8mln BPD from July to December 2020, followed by 6mln BPD from Jan 2021 to April 2022. The deal will be valid until the end of 2022, however subject to review in December 2021. The baseline is on oil production for October 2018, although Saudi and Russia baseline will be from 11mln BPD, according to Energy Intel.  Sources earlier noted Saudi and Russia would cut to 8.5mln BPD, which was later backed up by a draft document.
  • OPEC+ are to ask the G-20 for less than 5mln BPD in production cuts, earlier sources stated it would be 5mln bpd , according to Energy Intel.
  • Russia and Saudi Arabia agree to cut 2.5mln BPD, from the reported 11.0mln baseline, in line with earlier source reports.
  • Iraq is seen cutting 1.06mln BPD, UAE 720k, Kuwait 640k, Kazakhstan and NIgeria around 400k each in May to June.

MEETING (THUR)

  • Opening remarks now by the Saudi energy minister and following that there will be brief statements from the heads of delegation, then closed session; according to Energy Intel's Bakr
  • OPEC+ sources say the vibe so far is “very positive”, according to Energy Intel, there is a high probability of an OPEC+ agreement
  • Saudi and Russia have a deal on deep oil output cuts, according to OPEC source; senior Russian source says the two sides have agreed to remove their main obstacles to agreeing a new deal
  • OPEC++ to discuss bl cuts as large as 20mln BPD, according to one OPEC and Russian source - This was rebuffed by Energy Intels Bakr
  • Saudis, Russians agree in principle on a cut deal, Russia would cut 2mln BPD; working to make 20mln BPD disappear from the market, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • OPEC+ outline deal is for a 10mln BPD output cut, the deal is still being hammered out, targets may change according to Delegate
  • Delegate said OPEC+ will make full 10mln BPD cut for 2 months
  • OPEC+ said to seek as much as 5mln BPD from G20 nations (meeting Friday)
  • No specific numbers for cuts mentioned - will be discussed in closed session
  • Iraq and others are reportedly yet to agree on the production cut amount, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • No plans for a press conference

OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS
  • OPEC delegate says current options being considered range from a 10mln BPD cut to no cut
  • OPEC+ debates cuts in excess of 12mln BPD and wants others to contribute 5mln BPD, according to an OPEC+ source
  • Energy Intel Amena Bakr states they will discuss a 10-12mln BPD cut from May to June, and then an 8mln BPD cut from July to December 2020, then a 6mln BPD cut from Jan 2021 to April 2022, according to sources
  • OPEC+ reportedly discusses agreement on oil cuts that would last two years, according to two OPEC+ sources, in fitting with bullet point above
  • After a disagreement with Mexico, the nation later agreed to the deal and everyone came to an agreement. Overall, OPEC+agree to cut overall output by 10mln BPD from May 1st 2020 for 2 months, then 8mln BPD from July to December 2020, followed by 6mln BPD from Jan 2021 to April 2022. The deal will be valid until the end of 2022, however subject to review in December 2021. The baseline is on oil production for October 2018, although Saudi and Russia will be from 11mln BPD, according to Energy Intel.
  • OPEC+ are to ask the G-20 for less than 5mln BPD in production cuts, earlier sources stated it would be 5mln bpd , according to Energy Intel

TOUTED CUTS

  • Algeria oil minister said the emergency OPEC++ meeting will discuss a massive reduction in production which could reach 10mln bpd
  • Kuwait Oil Minister said that after talking with countries that will attend OPEC+ meeting, intention is moving towards reaching an agreement to lower output by a large amount between 10mln-15mln bpd
  • OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months, beginning in May, according to TASS
  • Several sources told Energy Intel that two scenarios will be presented: 1) First scenario sees OPEC+ being no longer bound by production restrictions (i.e. a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to production ~12mln BPD) 2) OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD cuts through the end of the year
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Arabia insists it can cut oil output only from the newly achieved levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD, according to a source briefed on Saudi policy
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 11th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official
  • Saudi Energy Minister tells OPEC+ that Saudi Arabia is ready to maintain oil cuts beyond 2022, according to an OPEC source

RUSSIA

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said

subject: US T-Note futures (M0) settled 13 ticks higher at 138-08
analysis_details: • The TPLEX traded choppy again as participants digested the latest Fed bazooka, gyrating OPEC+ sentiment, and minimal supply ahead of the long, Easter weekend. By settlement, yields were lower across the curve, lead by the belly, 2s -3bps at 0.23%, 5s -6bps at 0.41%, 10s -4bps at 0.72%, and 30s -1bps at 1.35%. Risk appetite had gotten off on the backfoot in European trade, as equity futures trundled lower alongside yields before the Fed announced its USD 2.3trln loan provision facilities which reversed the moves and nudged equities into a rally. The strength in Spooz going into the US session saw rates back up. However, the rally plateaued shortly after the cash equity open and saw support return for USTs - likely a function of jitters around the OPEC+ meeting and investors cutting risk exposure ahead of the long weekend. Meanwhile, corporate supply was sparse on Thursday, with no IG issuers in the dollar market, and with the Treasury’s auction reopenings out the way, there has been less selling pressure in Treasuries. Elsewhere, in credit, high-yield spreads narrowed on Thursday after the Fed’s latest announcement to support COVID-19 fallen angels (corporates that have seen their credit ratings downgraded to junk due to virus fallout), as well as high yield ETFs, with the day seeing a slew of headlines noting the spike higher in bonds of names such as Occidental (OXY) and Ford (F), amongst others. In the rates complex, three-month USD LIBOR posted a chunky 9bps decline for Thursday’s fixing, seeing the Eurodollar white pack stage a strong rally after Wednesday’s selling.

WTI (K0) settled USD 2.33 lower at USD 22.76/bbl; Brent (M0) settled USD 1.36 lower at USD 31.48/bbl
analysis_details: • The crude complex danced to the rhythm of the evolving OPEC+ meeting, ahead of the G20 oil meeting Friday, although ultimately moved lower into settlement as participants likely closed out positions heading into the long weekend. Headlines note that the May/June contango rose to over USD 6/bbl, the widest front-month spread since 2009. At time of writing, sources have reported that Saudi and Russia have agreed to both cut oil output to 8.5mln BPD in the OPEC+ deal from May to June, which would mark a 2.79mln BPD cut from Russia and 3.8mln BPD from Saudi compared to April levels. More broadly, several sources said, including the Iranian Oil Minister, that OPEC+ is set to discuss a 10-12mln BPD cut from May to June, and then an 8mln BPD cut from July to December 2020, then a 6mln BPD cut from Jan 2021 to April 2022. The Iranian Oil Minister gave some more colour, saying Iran, Venezuela and Libya are exempt from the cuts, with the touted cuts separate from the cuts expected of countries such as Brazil, Norway and the US. Ahead of the Friday’s G20 meeting, which will see the likes of the US, Canada and Norway come to the negotiating table, Canada’s Alberta Premier said the province has not been asked to cut output further and has made it clear to the US and OPEC that it has already curtailed output. Analysts have noted previously that it is most likely that the US and Canada will draw attention to the production cuts already taking place across their respective industries rather than agree to a government-enforced quota of such. The Alberta Premier went on to say that the municipal was getting very receptive responses from both Washington and Ottawa to placing tariffs on foreign oil if OPEC does not “stop the madness”. Click here for a complete collection of OPEC meeting related headlines.

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
Full newsquawk preview available here (8 Apr)

MEETING (THUR)

  • Opening remarks now by the Saudi energy minister and following that there will be brief statements from the heads of delegation, then closed session; according to Energy Intel's Bakr
  • OPEC+ sources say the vibe so far is “very positive”, according to Energy Intel, there is a high probability of an OPEC+ agreement
  • Saudi and Russia have a deal on deep oil output cuts, according to OPEC source; senior Russian source says the two sides have agreed to remove their main obstacles to agreeing a new deal
  • OPEC++ to discuss bl cuts as large as 20mln BPD, according to one OPEC and Russian source - This was rebuffed by Energy Intels Bakr
  • Saudis, Russians agree in principle on a cut deal, Russia would cut 2mln BPD; working to make 20mln BPD disappear from the market, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • OPEC+ outline deal is for a 10mln BPD output cut, the deal is still being hammered out, targets may change according to Delegate
  • Delegate said OPEC+ will make full 10mln BPD cut for 2 months
  • OPEC+ said to seek as much as 5mln BPD from G20 nations (meeting Friday)
  • No specific numbers for cuts mentioned - will be discussed in closed session
  • Iraq and others are reportedly yet to agree on the production cut amount, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • No plans for a press conference

OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS
  • OPEC delegate says current options being considered range from a 10mln BPD cut to no cut
  • OPEC+ debates cuts in excess of 12mln BPD and wants others to contribute 5mln BPD, according to an OPEC+ source
  • Energy Intel Amena Bakr states they will discuss a 10-12mln BPD cut from May to June, and then an 8mln BPD cut from July to December 2020, then a 6mln BPD cut from Jan 2021 to April 2022, according to sources
  • OPEC+ reportedly discusses agreement on oil cuts that would last two years, according to two OPEC+ sources, in fitting with bullet point above

TOUTED CUTS

  • Algeria oil minister said the emergency OPEC++ meeting will discuss a massive reduction in production which could reach 10mln bpd
  • Kuwait Oil Minister said that after talking with countries that will attend OPEC+ meeting, intention is moving towards reaching an agreement to lower output by a large amount between 10mln-15mln bpd
  • OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months, beginning in May, according to TASS
  • Several sources told Energy Intel that two scenarios will be presented: 1) First scenario sees OPEC+ being no longer bound by production restrictions (i.e. a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to production ~12mln BPD) 2) OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD cuts through the end of the year
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Arabia insists it can cut oil output only from the newly achieved levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD, according to a source briefed on Saudi policy
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 11th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official
  • Saudi Energy Minister tells OPEC+ that Saudi Arabia is ready to maintain oil cuts beyond 2022, according to an OPEC source

OTHERS

  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
MEETING (THUR)

  • Opening remarks now by the Saudi energy minister and following that there will be brief statements from the heads of delegation, then closed session; according to Energy Intel's Bakr
  • OPEC+ sources say the vibe so far is “very positive”, according to Energy Intel, there is a high probability of an OPEC+ agreement
  • Saudi and Russia have a deal on deep oil output cuts, according to OPEC source; senior Russian source says the two sides have agreed to remove their main obstacles to agreeing a new deal
  • OPEC++ to discuss bl cuts as large as 20mln BPD, according to one OPEC and Russian source - This was rebuffed by Energy Intels Bakr
  • Saudis, Russians agree in principle on a cut deal, Russia would cut 2mln BPD; working to make 20mln BPD disappear from the market, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • OPEC+ outline deal is for a 10mln BPD output cut, the deal is still being hammered out, targets may change according to Delegate
  • Delegate said OPEC+ will make full 10mln BPD cut for 2 months
  • OPEC+ said to seek as much as 5mln BPD from G20 nations (meeting Friday)
  • No specific numbers for cuts mentioned - will be discussed in closed session
  • Iraq and others are reportedly yet to agree on the production cut amount, according to WSJ's Said citing sources
  • No plans for a press conference

OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS
  • OPEC delegate says current options being considered range from a 10mln BPD cut to no cut
  • OPEC+ debates cuts in excess of 12mln BPD and wants others to contribute 5mln BPD, according to an OPEC+ source
  • Energy Intel Amena Bakr states they will discuss a 10-12mln BPD cut from May to June, and then an 8mln BPD cut from July to December 2020, then a 6mln BPD cut from Jan 2021 to April 2022, according to sources

TOUTED CUTS

  • Algeria oil minister said the emergency OPEC++ meeting will discuss a massive reduction in production which could reach 10mln bpd
  • Kuwait Oil Minister said that after talking with countries that will attend OPEC+ meeting, intention is moving towards reaching an agreement to lower output by a large amount between 10mln-15mln bpd
  • OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months, beginning in May, according to TASS
  • Several sources told Energy Intel that two scenarios will be presented: 1) First scenario sees OPEC+ being no longer bound by production restrictions (i.e. a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to production ~12mln BPD) 2) OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD cuts through the end of the year
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Arabia insists it can cut oil output only from the newly achieved levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD, according to a source briefed on Saudi policy
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 11th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official

RUSSIA

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said
  • Russia's Kremlin reiterated that Moscow wants joint co-ordinated actions to stabilise oil markets, and said a can hardly happen without others involvement
  • Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly coming closer to an agreement on an output deal, according to delegates but there reportedly is no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet, all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, according to RIA's Novosti
  • Russian and Saudi Arabian differences on an oil production cut deal are with regards to the volumes and baseline for any reduction, according to two OPEC sources
  • Russia is reportedly ready to cut production by 1.6mln BPD, according to Tass citing comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak, while other reports also noted Russia is ready to participate in the OPEC+ deal in line with its share in oil production of countries involved in the deal
  • Russia's maximum oil output cut under any global pact would be 2mln BPD, sources state - Kremlin declined to comment
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak tells the OPEC+ we need timely measures and all producers should join the effort, oil demand has fallen by 10-15mln BPD
  • Russian Wealth Fund Head Dmitriev says it is very important producers outside OPEC+ club join cuts; says some others will join measures during G20 on Friday

US

  • US President Trump said he did not make concessions during talks with Saudi and Russia on oil, while he did not agree to a US domestic production cut
  • US President Trump said nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, adding that US producers have cut back automatically as a reaction to the market
  • US independent oil producers reportedly told OPEC they will voluntarily cut output
  • US oil majors worry about antitrust issues if they join OPEC+ cuts
  • Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement

OTHERS

  • Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Indonesia, Norway, the UK, the US, and Trinidad & Tobago have been invited to take part in Thursday’s meeting, according to OPEC delegates cited by Energy Intel
  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts
  • Norway will have civil servants in attendance as observers at the OPEC+ meeting, Oil Minister will attend the G20 meeting tomorrow, according to the Oil Ministry
  • UAE’s Adnoc and Kuwait's KPC have delayed their May OSP releases until after the OPEC+ meeting
  • Iraqi Oil Minister says it is necessary to determine oil cuts limit, the timeline and the start date of applying the measures and distributing shares fairly and equally

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: Fed bangs the Buck, but boosts broad risk sentiment
content:
DXY

It’s debatable whether or not the Dollar was heading for a fall anyway given another record rise in the number of US initial claims, but the Fed removed doubt by unveiling its latest in an increasingly long line of credit easing packages at precisely the same time. In short, no less than Usd2.3 tn will be made available via an array of funding facilities including a Usd600 bn Main Street Lending Program targeting SMEs. The index tried to retain sight of the 100.000 mark, but could not withstand the weight of all round Greenback selling against major rivals and EM currencies as the aggressive stimulus gave flagging risk appetite a fillip. Indeed, the DXY declined to fresh wtd lows just a fraction above 99.400 compared to almost 101.000 at best and remained under pressure through downbeat/dovish commentary from Fed chair Powell pledging even more support for the economy without limit in terms of size, time or scope. From a chart perspective, April 2’s 99.335 now looms large.

AUD/NZD/CAD

The Aussie and Kiwi have gleaned more than fellow G10s from their US peer’s demise, as Aud/Usd probes above 0.6300 and Nzd/Usd tags along to top 0.6060, but the Loonie is also benefiting from a more pronounced rebound in crude prices amidst reports that OPEC+ and other global oil producers are planning to discuss an output cut of 20 mn bpd, even more than the 10-15 mn initially alluded to by US President Trump. In fact, Usd/Cad has posted a new weekly base at 1.3930 vs 1.4260 or so at the apex even though Canadian employment slumped by more than 1 mn in March ahead of next week’s BoC policy meeting.

GBP/EUR/CHF/JPY

Sterling has spent the bulk of the week monitoring the health of UK PM Johnson, but did stumble after a raft of data and especially yawning trade deficits against consensus and previous balances. However, the Pound eventually mustered enough momentum to breach several technical hurdles that had been hampering upside progress alongside updates from the hospital indicating that he is responding well to medication and in a more stable condition. Cable eclipsed 1.2475 and Eur/Gbp crossed through 200 DMA and Fib levels on the way to circa 0.8727 before the single currency reclaimed 1.0900+ status vs the Buck with some independent impetus via remarks from Germany’s Finance Minister Scholz suggesting that the Eurogroup is likely to find a resolution on a fiscal package to counter the COVID-19 economic fallout. Elsewhere, the renowned safe havens have not been sticking strictly to their roles, as overall swings in sentiment have intermingled with daily updates and vigils on nCoV cases and fatality rates. Meanwhile, the Franc and Yen have also been conscious of Swiss and Japanese efforts to cushion the blow from the global pandemic and both relatively contained within 0.9797-0.9651 and 109.37-108.36 parameters respectively, though ending the EU week close to peaks given the aforementioned Dollar weakness.

SCANDI/EM

Notwithstanding several hiccups and negative factors like disappointing data and general bouts of risk aversion, the Norwegian and Swedish Crowns remain on course to net hefty gains against the Euro (and Greenback), with the Nok bolstered by a full week of bigger Norges Bank purchases and Sek drawing encouragement from evidence that containment is having a positive effect on flattening the coronavirus curve elsewhere. Meanwhile, the Rouble and Mexican Peso have been supported by more stable Brent and WTI pending the outcome of OPEC+ and others, while the Real has clawed back from all time lows on BCB vibes after the Governor pledged to embark on more aggressive intervention. Similarly, the Rand and Lira have both pared heavy losses on better fundamental news in the form of Eskom contending that it has sufficient funds for the rest of the year and will not need to ask the SA Government to provide more financial assistance, while Turkey is said to have held constructive talks with the IMF.

  • Russia's maximum oil output cut under any global pact would be 2mln BPD, sources state - Kremlin declined to comment
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices

US

  • US President Trump said he did not make concessions during talks with Saudi and Russia on oil, while he did not agree to a US domestic production cut
  • US President Trump said nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, adding that US producers have cut back automatically as a reaction to the market
  • US independent oil producers reportedly told OPEC they will voluntarily cut output
  • US oil majors worry about antitrust issues if they join OPEC+ cuts
  • Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement

OTHERS

  • Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Indonesia, Norway, the UK, the US, and Trinidad & Tobago have been invited to take part in Thursday’s meeting, according to OPEC delegates cited by Energy Intel
  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts
  • Norway will have civil servants in attendance as observers at the OPEC+ meeting, Oil Minister will attend the G20 meeting tomorrow, according to the Oil Ministry
  • UAE’s Adnoc and Kuwait's KPC have delayed their May OSP releases until after the OPEC+ meeting

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
Full newsquawk preview available here (8 Apr)

N.B. Bold headlines = updates

MEETING (THUR)

  • Opening remarks now by the Saudi energy minister and following that there will be brief statements from the heads of delegation, then closed session; according to Energy Intel's Bakr
  • OPEC+ sources say the vibe so far is “very positive”, according to Energy Intel
  • Saudi and Russia have a deal on deep oil output cuts, according to OPEC source; senior Russian source says the two sides have agreed to remove their main obstacles to agreeing a new deal
  • OPEC++ to discuss oil cuts as large as 20mln BPD, according to one OPEC and Russian source

OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS
  • OPEC delegate says current options being considered range from a 10mln BPD cut to no cut

TOUTED CUTS

  • Algeria oil minister said the emergency OPEC++ meeting will discuss a massive reduction in production which could reach 10mln bpd
  • Kuwait Oil Minister said that after talking with countries that will attend OPEC+ meeting, intention is moving towards reaching an agreement to lower output by a large amount between 10mln-15mln bpd
  • OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months, beginning in May, according to TASS
  • Several sources told Energy Intel that two scenarios will be presented: 1) First scenario sees OPEC+ being no longer bound by production restrictions (i.e. a continuation of the current state of affairs - Saudi would stick to production ~12mln BPD) 2) OPEC members alongside Russia and other producers would implement joint 10mln BPD cuts through the end of the year
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Arabia insists it can cut oil output only from the newly achieved levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD, according to a source briefed on Saudi policy
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 11th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official

RUSSIA

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said
  • Russia's Kremlin reiterated that Moscow wants joint co-ordinated actions to stabilise oil markets, and said a can hardly happen without others involvement
  • Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly coming closer to an agreement on an output deal, according to delegates but there reportedly is no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet, all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, according to RIA's Novosti
  • Russian and Saudi Arabian differences on an oil production cut deal are with regards to the volumes and baseline for any reduction, according to two OPEC sources
  • Russia is reportedly ready to cut production by 1.6mln BPD, according to Tass citing comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak, while other reports also noted Russia is ready to participate in the OPEC+ deal in line with its share in oil production of countries involved in the deal
  • Russia's maximum oil output cut under any global pact would be 2mln BPD, sources state - Kremlin declined to comment
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices

US

  • US President Trump said he did not make concessions during talks with Saudi and Russia on oil, while he did not agree to a US domestic production cut
  • US President Trump said nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, adding that US producers have cut back automatically as a reaction to the market
  • US independent oil producers reportedly told OPEC they will voluntarily cut output
  • US oil majors worry about antitrust issues if they join OPEC+ cuts
  • Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement

OTHERS

  • Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Indonesia, Norway, the UK, the US, and Trinidad & Tobago have been invited to take part in Thursday’s meeting, according to OPEC delegates cited by Energy Intel
  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts
  • Norway will have civil servants in attendance as observers at the OPEC+ meeting, Oil Minister will attend the G20 meeting tomorrow, according to the Oil Ministry
  • UAE’s Adnoc and Kuwait's KPC have delayed their May OSP releases until after the OPEC+ meeting

US EQUITY OPEN: US equities open firmer aided by Fed's latest efforts while participants eye OPEC++, Fed's Powell and Eurogroup press conference
content:
MACRO: APAC trade continued the risk-on tone set by Wall Street. However, equity bourses began receding heading into the European open, with US futures trading in the red, although the Fed’s latest USD 2.3trln loan provision announcement has put bourses back into the green – note, one should consider an element of book squaring at play ahead of the long, Easter weekend. The risk aversion is seeing the TPLEX mixed with yields slightly lower across the curve, apart from the long end. DXY performance is lackluster beneath the 100-figure, while gold is bid around its weekly high, last at 1675. Meanwhile, the crude complex continues to dance to the rhythm of the OPEC++ meeting developments, currently firmer.

MARKET FOCUS: The OPEC++ meeting remains the centrepiece on Thursday (scheduled to start at 15:00 BST/10:00 ET), where participants are expecting the group to produce a landmark oil production cut to counter the oil price rout that has been causing reverberations for households, corporations, and governments globally. The latest source reports suggest Saudi can cut oil production from its newly hit levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD. Meanwhile, Fed Chair Powell is also due to make remarks at 10:00 ET. On the backburner, the Eurogroup meeting is scheduled to resume at 17:00 CET after the EZ finance minister failed to reach an agreement for EU-wide stimulus on Tuesday. The latest initial jobless claims saw a rise to 6.6mln from 6.5mln last week, above market consensus for a 5.25mln print, although within analyst ranges, where some called for over 9mln.

SECTOR THEMES: Energy names (XOM, CVX, COP, OXY), ahead of the OPEC+ call open firmer with the sector leading gains. Saudi Arabia’s Sovereign wealth fund took stakes worth approximately USD 1bln in four major European oil companies, Equinor (EQNR NO), Shell (RDS.A LN), Total (FP FP) and Eni (ENI IM)  according to reports citing people familiar with the matter, a Saudi official added they would not be surprised if we see similar deals again.  Airlines (LUV, DAL, AAL, UAL) aid worth USD 29bln for the sector is reportedly being delayed as companies have been required to provide more detailed financial data to regulators in an already lengthy process. Meanwhile, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin states airline aid is the next to be rolled out. Goldminers (NEM, GOLD) firmer amid higher gold prices following the Fed’s latest additional USD 2.3trln loan facility to support the economy.

US EQUITY STORIES: Pfizer Inc. (PFE) has reportedly found a promising but early treatment for the coronavirus, which it aims to begin testing in patients this summer, it found the experimental drug could slow or stop the spread of the virus in patients with mild to moderate symptoms. Microchip Technology (MCHP) announced it is cutting costs while expecting quarterly revenue to increase 3% (exp. -3.3%, prev. forecast 0%). MCHP noted the strength in bookings could be due to worries about supply chain disruptions, but it expects product demand is likely to weaken significantly. Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) net sales in March at USD 15.49bln, +11.7% Y/Y. Total comparable sales +9.6%, ex fuel +12.3%. Starbucks (SBUX) expect a Q2 20 EPS at USD 0.32/shr – USD 0.15-0.18 from prior guidance and expects Q3 impact to be significantly greater and to extend into Q4. General Electric (GE) withdrew its financial guidance due to the coronavirus, noting its preliminary view expects an impact on Adj. EPS to be USD 0.10 beneath prior guidance. Also expects Q1 industrial free cash flow to be near prior guidance of USD -2bln. 

SUPPLY & DEMAND: Nomura continues to class equity strength as bear market rally, mainly based on the result of central banks’ efforts to stanch the bleeding through bold easing measures. “The current rally is characterized by two features related to systematic supply and demand,” the bank notes, “The first feature is that bottoming in sentiment tends to trigger short-term factor reversals. We currently appear to be entering a phase in which investors buy back value (P/B) and dividend yield factors and sell quality (ROE) and low-vol factors. The second is that risk-parity funds have stopped net selling high-yield bonds. The weighting of high-yield bonds in risk-parity funds’ portfolios is nearing its lowest point since 2013 (around 20%), and risk-parity funds now appear to have stopped selling off high-yield bonds as part of their systematic rebalancing.” Nomura notes that in the near term, bearish positions look likely to continue to be closed out, and any further rallies would call for a “reality check”.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt slips and Dollar dips after yet more Fed stimulus
content: It goes without saying that timing is everything as far as financial markets are concerned, and conspiracy theorists may argue that Usd 2.3 tn additional funding from the Fed via an assortment of new credit facilities hit the headlines just as a fresh record high jobless claims figure broke. In response, bonds have drifted back further to make way for a rebound in stocks and general risk sentiment fillip, while the Greenback is net weaker, albeit could have been anyway given the aforementioned bleak data. Back to debt futures, Bunds are back under 171.00 from 171.09 at best, Gilts circa 136.45 vs 136.73 and 10 year T-notes sub-138-00 compared to 138-08+, with the DXY just off a new 99.656 trough as even Usd/Cad retreats from circa 1.4076 to 1.3980 in spite of Canadian monthly payrolls topping 1 mn.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 9th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

April 9th, 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, DAL, AAL, UAL), Aid worth USD 29bln for the sector is reportedly being delayed as companies have been required to provide more detailed financial data to regulators in an already lengthy process.
  • Of note for Energy names (XOM, CVX, COP, OXY), ahead of the OPEC+ call, Saudi Arabia’s Sovereign wealth fund took stakes worth approximately USD 1bln in four major European oil companies, Equinor (EQNR NO), Shell (RDS.A LN), Total (FP FP) and Eni (ENI IM)  according to reports citing people familiar with the matter, a Saudi official added they would not be surprised if we see similar deals again. Oil prices are very volatile this morning ahead of the key OPEC+ call with the latest suggesting Saudi can cut oil production from its newly hit levels of 12.3mln BPD and is ready to cut by 4mln BPD, according to sources.
  • Of note for Payment names (V, MA), Both payment networks have reportedly had swipe fee increases planned for months, according to WSJ. However, the plan was introduced before the coronavirus pandemic, and it is unclear whether the fee hikes will go ahead given the current conditions.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) supplier Hon Hai (HNHPF) has reportedly restarted iPhone 12 production but is taking extra precautions to ensure the health and safety of its employees.
  • Cisco Systems (CSCO) (Information Technology/Communications Equipment) CEO told its employees not to worry about job losses as it has the financial ability to continue paying employees and it does not want to contribute to the problem.
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is reportedly trying to sell Saudi PIF and UAE Mubadala loans to make new lending room, according to sources.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) will reportedly not deliver its Windows 10x-powered surface Neo dual-screen devices this year, adding it also plans to delay its Android-based Surface Duo beyond the holiday season, according to ZDNet.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has reportedly found a promising but early treatment for the coronavirus, which it aims to begin testing in patients this summer, it found the experimental drug could slow or stop the spread of the virus in patients with mild to moderate symptoms. However, human testing will be needed for certainty, according to WSJ.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) streaming service, Disney+, now has over 50mln subscribers across the globe.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class C (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - French Competition Authority are granting requests for urgent interim measures that presented by press publishers and AFP, would require Google (GOOG) to negotiate with relevant parties’ remuneration due under neighbouring rights law.
  • Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) announced it has withdrawn FY20 guidance and expects Q1 20 revenue between 4.22-4.23bln (exp. 4.21bln).
  • Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) Net sales (March) USD 15.49bln, +11.7% Y/Y. Total comparable sales +9.6%, ex fuel +12.3%.
  • Microchip Technology (MCHP) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) announced it is cutting costs while expecting quarterly revenue to increase 3% (exp. -3.3%, prev. forecast 0%). MCHP noted the strength in booking could be due to worries about supply chain disruptions, but it expects product demand is likely to weaken significantly.
  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) expects Q2 20 EPS to be down 0.15-0.18/shr to non-GAAP EPS. 0.32/shr (exp. 0.39). SBUX also withdrew FY20 guidance and noted the impact in Q3 would be significantly greater than Q2, and it will extend into Q4. Federal Reserve takes additional action to provide up to USD 2.3tln in loans to support the economy; will keep monitoring markets to see if more help is needed
content:
• Click here for link
  • Will assist households and employers of all sizes as well as state and local governments
  • Chair Powell says central bank's role is to 'provide as much relief and stability as we can' While country fights pandemic
  • Will purchase up to USD 600bln in loans through main street lending program aimed at small and midsize businesses using USD 75bln in capital from Treasury

The actions the Federal Reserve is taking today to support employers of all sizes and communities across the country will:

  • Bolster the effectiveness of the Small Business Administration's Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) by supplying liquidity to participating financial institutions through term financing backed by PPP loans to small businesses. The PPP provides loans to small businesses so that they can keep their workers on the payroll. The Paycheck Protection Program Liquidity Facility (PPPLF) will extend credit to eligible financial institutions that originate PPP loans, taking the loans as collateral at face value;
  • Ensure credit flows to small and mid-sized businesses with the purchase of up to $600 billion in loans through the Main Street Lending Program. The Department of the Treasury, using funding from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) will provide $75 billion in equity to the facility;
  • Increase the flow of credit to households and businesses through capital markets, by expanding the size and scope of the Primary and Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facilities (PMCCF and SMCCF) as well as the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF). These three programs will now support up to $850 billion in credit backed by $85 billion in credit protection provided by the Treasury; and
  • Help state and local governments manage cash flow stresses caused by the coronavirus pandemic by establishing a Municipal Liquidity Facility that will offer up to $500 billion in lending to states and municipalities. The Treasury will provide $35 billion of credit protection to the Federal Reserve for the Municipal Liquidity Facility using funds appropriated by the CARES Act.

PRIMER: Initial Jobless Claims at 13:30 BST / 09:30 ET
content: Last week’s jobless claims saw a record of 6.65mln jobs, with expectations for this weeks print likely to be somewhere similar with analysts expecting a print of 5.25mln, although the ranges vary from as low as 2.5mln to 9.295mln on the top end. Continued jobless claims expected at 8mln; ranges from 2.054mln to 13.2mln. Bank of America is expecting to see another 6.5mln print. The bank tracked headlines in 16 states which it estimates to be around 2.5mln, thus assuming a similar trend it would take the total to 6.5mln. BofA however believes that risks are tiled to the upside after seeing an increase in data from Google Trends shows an increase in searches for unemployment benefits and filing for unemployment, while it notes there were signs governments are adjusting to better process the filings, adding “some states believed the worst was yet to come”. The desk also highlights the passing of the CARES act and Coronavirus Aid Relief increases eligibility for jobless claims for other workers and boost the maximum number of weeks that one can receive benefits. The desk adds this creates an incentive for businesses to temporarily furlough employees as they will be financially covered. However, seasonal factors could have an impact, “combining last week’s non-seasonally adjusted figure of 5.8mln with this week’s lower seasonal factor would result in seasonally adjusted claims of 6.2mln instead of 6.6mln that was actually reported.”
